comments.content: The customized version of Apple Myriad used on-screen is called Lucida Grande. If you have Lucida Sans, you can also use that since it’s almost exactly the same.

While they both could be called humanist sans, Myriad and Lucida are two different typefaces.

Myriad was designed by a team at Adobe, led by Carol Twombly and Robert Slimbach:  
 [http://store.adobe.com/type/browser/P/P\_1706.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20090430074106/http:/store.adobe.com/type/browser/P/P_1706.html "http://store.adobe.com/type/browser/P/P\_1706.html")

Lucida Grande is a display version of Lucida Sans. Both were designed by Kris Bigelow and Charles Holmes:  
 [http://store.adobe.com/type/browser/P/P\_1359.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20090430074106/http:/store.adobe.com/type/browser/P/P_1359.html "http://store.adobe.com/type/browser/P/P\_1359.html")

Well, I meant that while Apple Myriad is used in print, Lucida Grande is the font used on screen. So, the choice depends on your display medium.

Sorry if I caused any confusion.
